The movie is nominated for many awards and it had won few. There are many online forums and discussion debating the movie's ending. It really is a mind boggling climax. I am sure that you will question your sanity after watching this flick.

title: Awesome movie, just awesome
review:
i am not a regular movie viewer but as my friend suggest highly to watch this movie, i watched it and really enjoyed the movie.

when i read Dennis Lehane (novel), i think that the movie will be a great one, and that is really- as Director Martin Scorsese direct the movie awfully. don't miss the movie.

i am always a fan of Leonardo di Caprio, and seeing his acting in this movie my love to him increases a lot.

visual effect is very very charming and nice. where the movie shooting take place- is also nice.

As a hurricane cuts off communication with the mainland, more dangerous criminals "escape"- and then the real thrill start, as Teddy have to begin to doubt everything.

movie goes through suspect, twist and i assure, you can not left your seat until the movie end.

if you like thriller based movie ,i suggest you to watch this movie must.

title: Read the book first, then watch the movie potential spoilers!
review: I like reading the book first then watching the movie. Martin Scoreses did the film and it was an okay film but it wasn't nearly as good as the book was. ( same title ) There is just something thrilling from reading about the characters than watching Leonardo Dicaprio on film. I did enjoy that the film was set in a different era, and I did like the insane asylum feel to it and the who dun it. However, the ghost story aspect left was ended too quickly for me to get into it or the way the film maker did it left me cold ( no pun intended ) all in all, I would recommend this film, if you're looking for a SuckerPunch-esque kind of film.

title: One of the best thrillers
review: For me, SHUTTER ISLAND is one of the best thrillers I have ever seen. The story starts with a simple plot but starts getting complicated every minute. The location and the "early 90s" setup looked very attracting and once you start watching the movie you cannot leave without completing. Also Di Caprio, as usual, played the role in the best of ways. One more thing about the movie is that if you see the movie 2 or 3 times, we come to know that the dialogues that were being said by various characters actually had two meanings which we can only understand at the end of the movie or the next time we see it again. I will rate it 10/10.

title: One of the Greatest Emotional Thrillers
review:
A movie, an emotional ride, a work of art. There are many ways to describe Martin Scorsese and Leonardo DiCaprio's Shutter Island (2010). This film does something that very little other film can do, It keeps you in the dark and confused about the characters past, present and future while also drawing you very attached to them all with crazy and obscure symbols. The way they accomplish this is a riveting story line mixed with incredible scenery, lighting, color and sound, while the entire movie giving you hints about his past without you even knowing. The thing that is most shocking and breathtaking in this movie though is the acting. All the characters don't even feel like they are on a movie screen. It seems as though you are standing right next to them as all of this is happening right before your eyes because the acting is the best I think I've ever seen in anything, mainly from Leo Deo(Leonardo DiCaprio).

Let me give you the intro to the movie. It starts out following a man named Teddy played by Leo Deo and his partner Chuck played by Mark Ruffalo. They are federal Marshall's sent to Shutter Island(an island which only has a mental hospital on it.) to help investigate a missing patient at a who seemingly vanished. That's all I'm going to say about the story line because I will be mainly be talking about the execution of the movie itself, the story is amazing and I'd love to talk about it but I honesty feel like the story is something you discover on your own so just talking even a little about it would take away from such a great movie. It has so many twists and turns as more and more is revealed to you that it keeps you at the edge of your seat the whole movie. That being said, throughout the entire movie they somehow are able to draw upon your emotions and make you question certain things without them even telling you, just based on the eerie music, lighting and ludicrous dream sequences. There are many many symbols/ important statements said and shown throughout the movie that they don't even address and you don't notice until the end that they were even there. They keep you guessing so much that it seems the audience is so focused on the big picture that they don't see the clues right in front of them. It is incredible how they are able to hold the audiences attention just with the mood, scenery, and sound while constantly feeding you information that you try to make sense of in your head which draws you even deeper into the movie.

When you watch this movie, I want you to pay attention to the dream sequences very closely. Look and listen to what the characters are saying, wearing and their reactions to each other. It is insane the amount of detail and thought goes into these scenes and at first you just see the scenes as a confusing gaze into Teddy's past, but there are so many secrets to be found in the entire movies but especially in these very emotional and symbolic scenes of the film. Just looking at how the characters interact with each other is a treat because the execution of all the scenes is flawless. Take this dream scene for example, Teddy is walking near a pile of bodies at a concentration camp and he sees a woman and child dead on top of each other. The little girl eerily gets up and whispers that he should have saved her and all of "us". Then he is now walking through a very fancy house where he encounters the man that burned his apartment to the ground and killed his girlfriend. They stare each other down next to a fire as he plays with matches and he lights his cigarette. There is so much more to this scene, but for the sake of space lets just look at this. The heartache, shock, and regret on his face as he sees the girl rise and stare him down paints such an amazing picture and lets you know exactly how the characters feel and just how bad Teddy's past is. When he see's Latus, the anger and hatred on his face is so believable, it really draws you into the characters and makes you want to know exactly what is going on with them on the inside and out. The music and noises of these scenes only add to the incredible tension that you can just feel even through the screen. This movies feels like an emotional roller-coaster as you are trying just as hard as Teddy to figure out what is happening. It feels like you and Teddy are figuring it out together which makes you feel even more attached.

Like I said earlier, one of the best, if not the best tool that they use to draw on your emotions is the acting. Seeing every tear, every outburst and every wrinkle in all the characters faces as they traverse through this hell on earth is so believable and so heart wrenching that I feel like this pulls you in more than any other of the tools they use. We are all human and we all have feelings and pasts so it is easy for us to relate to other people who are going through something as crushing as this. It is something that all humans share, we have a past, we laugh, we cry, and we cherish moments. They use this truth like I've never seen before. Seeing the pain from Teddy's face and the anguish he is going through on the inside tears a hole in your heart because he plays such a perfect Teddy, that it doesn't feel like a character anymore, it feels like a friend.

title: crazy movie
review: I give this movie a 10 for blowing my mind and scaring the crap out of me... This is hands down the most intense and crazy movie i've ever seen in my life. they way he's chasing the guy down seems like he's actually doing so, and than it turns out he's the one who escaped? It was so messed up and scared me like crazy. I definitely had my mind blown by this movie, if you like movies like that, id say go see it, it's definitely worth seeing, I've watched it about 10 times just because I'm always shocked by it. There's no movie other than Inception that has been as intense as this one. Leo is such an amazing actor too! Just don't let kids watch this..

title: Lots of Twists and Suspense
review:
Finally got around to watching this on DVD, and this film was nothing like what I expected. However, I give it a 7. I am still unsure whether I liked it or not. I did find it fairly disturbing and I can say that I have not been as genuinely disturbed by a film since The Machinist which nearly made me physically sick and messed me up for days - and I am a fan of horrors like Saw! I think De Caprio is a very talented actor. However the fact that he looks about 17 just makes it unbelievable when he is playing a role where he is supposed to have some kind of authority. It doesn't work for me. An example is where he has his top off next to his partner. Leo has the smooth body of a child he also has crappy tattoos that I just don't feel a US Marshall would have had in 1954! I also find Ben Kingsley to be a very one dimensional actor. Psycho one or psycho 2. He is good in this but I find it impossible to get the image of him as Don Logan in Sexy Beast out of my head. He seems to be the "dial a nutter"! We need a phsychopatic actor - phone SIR Ben and see if he is available. I find it hard to take him seriously.

Michelle Williams acts well in this and I found it quite poignant seeing what has happened in her personal life. There is just something too plain about her that i feel she has blagged her way into Hollywood and is not really a star.

The stand out performance for me was Mark Ruffalo. I have never seen his work before and he stole the show for me. I kept thinking it was Billy Zane and had to keep reminding myself that he is bald! The "twist" becomes so obvious that I was waiting for another one. Is that it I was thinking? Yes, the score was haunting but at times I felt it was too much.

I think Marty needs to get back to his gangster roots and make a modern day gangster flick using less obvious A list stars and sourcing his actors from some of the amazing TV shows like The Shield, The Sopranos and OZ.

Mark Ruffalo would make a perfect leading actor as he has that ambiguous "foreign" look about him.

All in all a disturbing, dark film that hits wide off the mark in my opinion.

title: A Great new experience out of an hackneyed plot.
review:
So many times have we seen a movie which ends the way Shutter Island does. But this movie explains what difference a great story teller, what Martin Scorsese is, can do to any script, any story or film given to him.

Even though many of you would get a hint of a part of the ending while watching, the way I got, but still it didn't take anything away from the film. Just after watching for the first time I got irritated slightly and started cursing the film maker for messing up the whole plot but then I realized that it is where the greatness of the film lies.

The film is very engrossing, captivating and a must watch. It is not a film you can watch with a popcorn and a soda in your hands. You have to tickle your brain nerves to really enjoy it. Martin has really worked very hard to bring each and every detail perfectly out on the screen and you should do justice by watching it sedulously. If you do not do so, you would be blaming it on the ending, but this is a film where the body of the film makes such an impact that ending becomes just a puppet of it.

It is supposed that mystery movies are enjoyable only once, but it is such a good film that you can watch it several times without getting bored. The plot has been woven together so deftly that even when the mystery is out in the end you are able to relate it so easily to the subtleties that it all becomes very convincing, but again for that you have to watch the movie with a great focus and respect for the genre and the film maker.

title: Mind-Boggling, Simply Outstanding
review:
When I first saw the trailer of 'Shutter Island', I thought it to be a horror flick and I thought, what is Martin Scorsese is doing with this horror film ??? Apparently I got my answer after seeing the movie, and I am happy that I am wrong. Story wise, this is definitely one of the best thrillers that I have seen. The twists and turns in this story were simply great. With a Genius like Martin Scorsese as director, this movie will keep you at the edge of your seat. In the movie ' The Prestige ' a magic trick is said to have three acts- The Pledge, The Turn and The Prestige. The Prestige is the final and most important act because it will make the magic trick memorable. Similarly, the last couple of twists, which I like to call the Prestige, in the story of 'Shutter Island' will make your jaw drop. The work of Martin Scorsese was good as usual. He was able to portray the story well and gave the story its proper value. The cinematography was very good.

The performance of Mark Ruffalo, Ben Kingsley were phenomenal. Also the acting of Michelle Williams was very good. The performance of these guys made the twists and turns to develop.

Now on the downside of the movie was the performance of Leonardo DiCaprio. Though he did a fare job, but it was not a great performance for me. Somehow in all his movie, every character becomes all the same. Its as if, rather than Leonardo becoming the character, the character becomes Leonardo.

At the end, I recommend everyone to watch this film, especially thriller loving people. Because This movie will simply blow your minds away.

title: amazing
review:
I just saw Shutter Island this evening, just prior to its American release. I have to say this film was full of intrigue. Prior to viewing this film I had built a preconceived notion of what this thriller was going to be like because I was fooled yet again by good marketing when watching the trailer. I loved it when leos character teddy turns out to be insane and he was the one who actually murdered his wife and kids! The doctor who starts off as the antagonist and ends up as the protagonist! Amazing Shutter island is a must watch!

his performance is brilliant, so much range to his character. In fact all of the acting in this film is excellent. The directing is probably the best quality to this film. I always enjoy watching a film that is as unpredicatable as this film and where the director has turned the plot line on to his viewer.

title: Amazing film
review: This is one of the best films I've ever seen. Completely tricked me and loved the ending. Second time was just as good! The only reason I'm writing this review is because it's frustrating seeing the negative reviews shutter island has been receiving. Many saying it was "too predictable" or that it has a boring ending!? Perhaps if you spent a little time actually watching the film rather than guessing the ending non stop (hate people who do that),you wouldn't give such a close minded/boring opinion. You may actually enjoy a film for once rather than looking for tiny little mistakes that are made. Also to the people who didn't like the ending. I don't know what film you were watching, considering it constantly left me and my friends questioning ourselves. But anyway... In my opinion the only people who wouldn't enjoy this film are the smart arse boring types. To everyone else I am sure you will love it! Watch with an open mind :)

title: Awesome Film, Awesome Twist, Awesome Acting
review:
A film like this is appreciated with repeated viewings, much like the Machinist, The Prestige, Fight Club, Memento, The Uusual Suspects, The Sixth Sense, Psycho, Saw, Identity, basically anything with a real good twist.

Not a lot of Scorcese movies have big twist outside the Departed but that was just because of what happens to the characters rather then a plot twist.

The twist here makes so much sense. I have seen this film four times now and have liked it more each time.

The whole movie you just want to know what is going on. You want to know why is everything so mysterious, why does Leo have these headaches, why are people being sketchy outside of it being a hospital for the criminally insane.

A lot of visually striking, eerie shots in this film. Scorcese does a wonderful job as always, and Leo is Leo. Top notch acting, one of his very best performances.

This movie is in my collection now and very high on my list.

You will not regret seeing this movie, it is not for everybody but you cant help but respect it.

A great, great story!

9 out of 10

title: A frightening mystery
review:
Crime thriller films don't come much better than this. Shutter Island has great actors, a spooky atmosphere and a story that starts intriguing and develops into a sprawling masterpiece. The film deals with an investigation of a criminal asylum where one patient has inexplicably gone missing.

Leonardo DiCaprio is a tough cop with a past as a soldier in the Allied forces and traumatizing memories of the Nazi crimes they saw. Ben Kingsley is the chief of the institution who seems to be holding something back. Mark Ruffalo is DiCaprio's steadfast partner and Michelle Williams DiCaprio's loving wife.

The film works better on the second viewing and has a great emotional impact. When the complex story has completely unfolded it reveals a hauntingly moving film.

title: One of my favorite Dicaprio flicks
review:
Shutter Island is my favorite type of movie. It has a complex plot, amazing acting, and stunning atmosphere. If you liked The Prestige or The Sixth Sense, this could possibly become one of your favorites.

Contrary to what the trailer leads you to believe this movie is not horror, its suspense. It literally IS suspense. From the opening minute I was enthralled in the dialogue and atmosphere. I couldn't help but analyze every word for clues about the characters true motives. I wasn't sure who to trust except for Teddy (Played by Leonardo DiCaprio) and his partner Chuck (Mark Ruffalo). The movie is set in 1954 Boston on an Island occupied by the mentally insane. Chuck and Teddy are U.S. Marshals investigating a missing persons case. Right away you can tell something's up. I'll let you decide on a theory for yourself, because if I went into the plot in detail it would only ruin some of the twists and turns. Don't miss a single scene, because there are subtle hints throughout the movie that you will pick up on if you pay attention to the details. In fact, I actually was able to predict some of the happenings near the end; which was somewhat disappointing. It didn't detract too much, and I certainly didn't understand all of what was going on. On a second viewing you actually gain a real respect for how much everything makes sense. There wasn't any plot holes that I caught. This movie is actually based on a book of the same name. If not sure how close it is to the original considering that I haven't read it, but I'd be shocked if you weren't satisfied with the adaption simply because it's such a well-directed film.

The cinematography in this movie is amazing. Each scene has a well thought out color pattern; blue hues and foggy grays abound. The lighting in each scene was perfect. Just right in the intense moments so you can't see all the details. At one point Teddy is holding a match that is lighting the room around him. When the match goes out the screen goes black and you can't see anything until he lights another match. It was very intense. The atmosphere is always eerie because of the island itself. It's always foggy or storming. It almost has a supernatural feeling. Some moments are especially frightening. In one of the final scenes when you see what has really happened; it's actually quite disturbing. The movie doesn't scare you with piles of gore, just its unstable characters. The "Patients" are grotesque. The makeup people did a superb job of making the most realistically scary faces. The soundtrack is haunting. It builds the tension to a boiling point. It's one of those scores where if it came on you would instantly say "Oh that's from Shutter Island!" Over all I have no complaints with any of the technical aspects of the movie.

I can't do a review of this movie without mentioning the outstanding acting. As usual Leonardo DiCaprio puts on amazing show. This movie is really all about him. He has the uncanny ability to reel the audience in with his emotion. The reason you are uneasy as you watch is because DiCaprio sells that you should be. Trust me, once you get to know all about the character Teddy you'll realize just how amazing his performance is. Mark Ruffalo was very good as well. He played a good Watson to Leonardo's Sherlock. When you know what to look for in a second viewing you can see a lot of subtle facial expressions that are hints of things to come. Ben Kingsley's Dr. Cawley was suitably bold. I was honestly cheering against him. After the credits rolled though, I realized that he was acting perfectly for his character's situation. Max Von Sydow was chilling as Dr. Naehring. He had a lighthearted evil about him. The rest of the cast was good as well. No bad acting to report.

This movie is among my favorites. It's not quite a perfect ten, but it's close. You get pulled in from the start by the acting and story. I can't recommend it enough if you like suspense/mystery movies.

tkuba1.wordpress.com

title: Plays with your mind... amazing!
review: Shutter Island is sinister. Every twist and turn will leave you with some questions answered and some asked. At first, Teddy seems sane, but some things about him seem off. Over time, you see his nightmares and flashbacks. They're haunting. Creepy. He is troubled by the death of his wife, and we see her multiple times, as she tells him to do things in dreams and in his "reality." We also see dead children and other horrifying things. It then becomes clear that he is not fully sane. Then it is revealed that he killed his wife, who drowned his children, and he doesn't want to accept that. He had been living in his alternate world as a US Marshal, not a killer. However, you will be left guessing. There are multiple theories you can draw about different things in this movie, but all of them leave you wanting to watch it again and again.

title: awesome movie (y) (y)
review:
I say only one thing see it once and u would like to see twice..

There is a quote that leaves us pondering: "Which would be worse, to live as a monster or to die as a good man?" For me, what it means is that DiCaprio chose to erase his memory and die a good man. The reason to it is simple. One of the saddest and toughest aspects of life is to have a good memory. Memories are what shape us, but also is what makes us more cynical and bitter about the world. At the end of the day, Martin Scorsese has created a movie that allows the audience to come up with their own viewpoint of what happens. Whether that is a good or bad thing, it is really the way you approach and think..

title: Don't Miss this film!
review:
This film takes an intelligent person to understand it's full potential! So much psychology involved. Great details!

Greatstory-line!

Great acting... Just phenomenal! Keeps you guessing, and asking questions..

great ending! Very twisted and eerie. :)

Great acting by the man characters!

I loved it!

Whenever I saw it I went out and bought it the next day.

A movie to watch with a significant other!

Great movie night choice!

title: remarkable
review: result of a great meeting, it is a labyrinth. dark, strange, seductive. good occasion to discover precise art of Leonardo di Caprio and for admire science of detail of Scorsese. basic, it is an adaptation. a policier with usual ingredients. but this is just trap. in fact, it is an arena for the desire to create a very fragile universe, not only as thriller but like ball of questions. and all instruments are used. shadows, stories, ambiguity as perfect drug, each scene as a fog isle. key - script, of course. but, more important, perfection of performance. and preoccupation for right equilibrium. nothing more. but result is real impressive. and nice seed for new re-view of film.

title: Shutter Island Is a movie that you will never forget
review:
Shutter Island is the best mystery movie of all time. It is on my list of top movies that I've ever seen. Shutter Island, set in 1954, has a lot of eeriness and mystery to it throughout the movie.It has great acting, and is like the first season of lost, only darker.

Shutter Island has a rich storyline. It's plot is about a U.S. Marshall and WW2 vet named Teddy Daniels, and his new partner, Chuck Aule. They are investigating the mysterious disappearance of a patient at the most advanced Mental Penitentiary in the U.S. which is located on it's own island. Which turns out there is more to the Island than it seems, and Teddy Daniels.

A lot of parts in the movie Teddy has twisted dreams that seem to have no meaning. Each one involving death.Like when he is in a dining hall and Teddy hears a scream. He turns around to find the patient he is looking for covered in blood and a dead child on the floor. Then the scene cuts to him putting the child in a lake, the dead child asks Teddy how he could let it happen to her, "I am so sorry" replied Teddy. All of the dreams seem to have no meaning until the end. Another crazy part in the movie is when Teddy is walking down one of the hallway of Ward C(I wont spoil what happens).When everything in the movie adds up.

There is a few reasons why you might not want to see the movie. There is a large amount of blood used in it, and there is only a small amount of gore in the WW2 scenes. There is also a lot of language and some sexual reference in some scenes. If you're not okay with some of these things you might not want to watch this movie.

This movie has great acting. A good example is Chuck, Teddy's partner. He has this mafia like way of talking which was common at that time. Also Teddy's wife does great acting and is very emotional. This movie sets its eeriness a lot within the way the characters act.

Shutter Island is and all-time great movie. It has an ingenious storyline and ending, it has great acting, and an amazing feel to it. If you watch this movie, It will be one that you will never forget.

title: Scorsesse Strikes Brilliance Again(****Out Of****)
review:
Belated Day 28 Of My 31 Days Of Horror 2.

Scorssese hits brilliance with this film. The film follows Teddy Daniels played by Leonardo DeCaprio who in the 1950's goes to investigate a mental hospital and investigates a murder of a woman whom he suspects is still roaming around on the island.

Not too much to say but the acting is superb and the vibe and atmosphere is done very well. I would really like to see more films like this instead of the usual killer going after the stupid teenagers.

Rated R For Disturbing Violent Content, Language And Some Nudity.

2hrs 18min/138min.

14 uses of the F-word.

****/****

title: A weary but gratifying experiment.
review:
Shutter Island exemplifies Martin Scorsese's wonderful intelligence and illuminations of motion picture art as an performer and now director. The mystery behind the fogginess suggests a bleak elude eeriness with this film, revealing an unexpected yet incredible finale. The camera also adopts feelings of apprehension, giving it a frantic feel and a true crime investigatory mind set. In addition, we see how DiCaprio's acting capabilities have become more convincing and have improved through age since his heroics in Titanic. This is potentially one of Scorsese's most experimental pieces of film making. His delicate perception of how sound and camera movement blend quite beautifully to create significant meanings and tempers, covering the picture with a blanket of vagueness and trepidation.

Set in 1954, U.S. Federal Marshal Teddy Daniels (Leonardo DiCaprio) embarks on an investigation into the mysterious disappearance of a patient by the name Rachel Solando, who has escaped or been potentially slaughtered at an asylum institute for the criminally insane. As Teddy tip-toes around the derelict Island he discovers more than he would have wished for, including a few home truths that reveal themes of true identity and false recognition of the enemy. Teddy's character recognition and re-acknowledgment of haunting images from his time serving during the Second World War, with visionaries of his army unit releasing free a Nazi concentration camp and the death of his wife and two children truly capture the emotion that Scorsese, Kalogridis and Lehane attempt to reveal to the narratives admirers. He begins to have reservations with his own memory, his wife and even his personal wisdom due the experience of radical experiments put in order by the mental institute, causing confusion and a host of suspects. As Terry and Chuck (Mark Ruffalo) find themselves marooned on the island, Teddy begins interrogating the internees, finding a haunting and unexpected hidden secret relating to Shutter Island.

DiCaprio's notions of confusion, conspiracy and misplaced sense of direction really give his character an incredible unbalanced movement, especially considering when detectives are supposed to steer from paranoia. Although his temperament is full of perplexity, Teddy fails to realise he has become the mechanism of a psychological experiment. This truly illustrates DiCaprio's maturity as a performer, feeding upon Scorsese's filming intelligence, congratulating the late 1960s psychological terror era on influence on tails such as this.

title: One View Is Just Not Enough
review:
Could any Scorsese/DiCaprio movie possibly go wrong?! I loved every minute of Shutter Island. The brilliant script is brought to perfection by DiCaprio's exquisite, getting-maturer-by-the-day performance and Scorsese's unfailing ability to entertain both your eye and mind.

The movie is a perfect thriller that will have you watch the movie more than once to pick up what you missed and put the pieces together. Even the twists and turns, as they unfold, make the movie richer both story- wise and suspense-wise without sacrificing the verisimilitude. And never think you've got it all after the first viewing, the second and the third, will surprise you even the more and leave you wondering what to believe.

Everyone in the movie's ensemble seems to know exactly what they are doing. I don't know whether it's the Scorsese effect or all of them are really good actors. Ben Kingsley is a master of his art as usual. Patricia Clarkson and Emily Mortimer, despite their small roles, flavored the film with some topnotch performance. As for Mr. Ruffalo, he has officially moved from my "Can't Stand" List to my "Likable" List.

title: Flawed
review:
I think Shutter Island is quite a mixed bag, but overall I was fairly pleased with it. Strong beginning and ending. Unfortunately, the stuff in between rather sucked. It's actually quite a mess in there. If only it had been not so muddled and more taut and believable, Shutter Island would've picked up more points.

Still, good asmosphere, solid acting, creepy characters, good setting, amazing music. Listen to 'On the Nature of Daylight' and you know what I mean.

Recommended, but with reservations.

Hey, at least it's better than Inception and Black Swan combined.

title: A Thrilling, Suspenseful and Mystifying Tale
review:
One probably wouldn't associate Martin Scorsese with a psychological thriller, but this film was deftly handled by the master director.

The film's premise is relatively simple: two United States Marshals are summoned to a remote mental institution to find an escaped patient. However nothing is as it seems at Ashcliffe (the name of the hospital) once the Marshals begin their investigation and fear their sanity is fading away. There are many twists and turns as the film delves into the tortured psyche of anti-hero, Edward "Teddy" Daniels (Leonardo DiCaprio). The climax is truly dramatic and brings the film's action full circle, but I will not reveal the surprise.

Leonardo DiCaprio aptly portrays the former alcoholic Teddy Daniels, a man whose dark past continuously haunts him throughout the film; particularly the tragic death of his wife (Michelle Williams) which is kept secret for the majority of the film's run-time until the end of the film. DiCaprio brings out the vulnerability needed for the part, but also has a strong reserve in his actions.

DiCaprio's chemistry with co-star, Mark Ruffalo who plays Daniels's partner Chuck Aule, provides the profound revelations that drive the narrative forward. Both actors play off each other in the fashion of a cat and mouse game as their pasts remain obscure until Teddy eventually tells some secrets to Chuck that spell the former's downfall.

The film's supporting cast of Michelle Williams as DiCaprio's wife, Ben Kingsley as Dr. Cawley and Max von Sydow as the asylum head, all add mounting suspense as their motives. Williams in particular plays a deceased character and remains a haunting presence as she is the driving force behind DiCaprio's Teddy's fractured mind; telling him to avenge her death. Kingsley and von Sydow stay subtle in their roles as psychiatrists; their motives remaining murky until the final act of the film.

If you have a taste for mind games, give this a viewing cause you'll want to see it again.

title: Too mind-twisting, Scorsese has made better stuff
review:
Actors are excellent (DiCaprio has pleasantly surprised me again), but the plot has its shortcomings -- there are so many issues unsolved or unexplained, e.g. whom did the main character meet in reality or why he suffered his illnesses. The movie itself is a bit lengthy (suspense is sometimes lost), and the ending is too sophisticated as well.

Director and cameramen, however, have done nice work, making Shutter Island definitely an A-movie. But, in my opinion, The Others and The Sixth Sense (among others) are better. But if you just like to experience in common or like to be captivated by gloominess and mystery, then this movie is meant for you :)

title: Well-written plot with an excellent execution
review:
This is my favorite genre, films with a self-referential architecture. The obvious structure of the film has two main layers with subtle variations of those two layers throughout the film. First layer is Teddy being an investigator and the second layer is Teddy being a mental patient playing an investigator. The variations come about with different characters exposing sub-plots, such as the Nazi schemes, while Teddy plays the investigator. The layers constructed as 'a very delicate but intricate architecture.' Scorcece did a superb job in threading the layers together with interesting lines throughout the film. However, considering that it was released in 2010, after films like 'Identity,' it could have more depth to it...maybe by relating the film situation more directly with our everyday lives. Besides that, the film had a good balance of intriguing plot and entertaining thriller elements. Also, DiCaprio added much color to the plot. He seems to be on an evolving track as far as this kind of acting is concerned, starting from 'Catch Me If you Can' to 'Inception.'

Her delusions...are conceived on a very delicate but intricate architecture. To sustain that structure, she employs and elaborate narrative thread to her life that is completely fictitious. And she gives us all parts to play in that fiction.

title: Worth a look
review:
Other reviewers have mentioned The Cabinet of Dr Caligari to which I would add Marat/Sade and One Flew Over the Cuckoos Nest as exploration pieces into insanity.

But despite its flaws and plot holes, I found Shutter Island to be a worthwhile piece of entertainment, if you go along for the ride.

Leo does a good job, and I am not his biggest fan, and the Nazi connection, apparently a figment of his imagination makes sense when you put it into the context of his insanity and the role played by Max von Sydow.

This is not going to be everyones cup of tea but if it is treated with respect and if not over analysed, it does actually work quite well. It is technically well done, generally well acted and for me at least, was quite suspenseful most of the way.

I think critics who have dismissed it are being harsh, but I also think its fundamental flaws stop it being a 9 or 10. Recommended.

title: Patient # 67
review:
***MAJOR SPOILERS*** Sent in the fall of 1954 to this far off island off Boston Harbor US Marshall Edward "Teddy" Daniels, Leonardo DiCairo, is given a new partner Marshall Chuck Aule, Mark Ruffalo, who came to Boston all the way from Seattle Washington. The case that both Marshall Danials & Aule are to investigate is the escape from the island's top security Ashecliffe Mental Hospital, that's run by the US Government, of child murderess of her own three children Rachel Solando,Patrica Clarkson. Both Daniels & Aule run into a number of roadblocks in their investigation in that the person who runs the hospital Dr. John Cawley, Ben Kingsly,and his assistant Dr. Jeremiah Naehring, Max Von Sydow,refuse to cooperate with them in releasing the escapee's, Rachel Solando,personal medical records! In fact as both Daniel's and Aule soon come to realize that this Rachel Solando may not even exist at all!

As the film plays itself out is soon becomes evident that it's Marshall Daniels who's suffering from a series of jolting and mind bending flashbacks coupled with migraine headaches who's a candidate to be locked up in Ashecliffe Hopital just as much as the escaped child murderess Rachel Solando is! We get to see Daniels's mind start to work on him in two events in his life that has changed him forever. His involvement in the liberation of the Nazi concentration camp Dachau in the spring of 1945, when he was 22, and what, in the hundreds of dead and emaciated bodies of the camp inmates, he saw there. What was also playing on Daniel's mind is the cold blooded massacre of over 500 unarmed and helpless German Army & SS prisoners at the camp that he participated in! The second and far more personal event in Daniel's life that's been burning him up for the last two years is the death of his wife Dolores, Michelle Williams,who died in an arson fire of the couple's home set by firebug and confirmed psycho Andrew Laddis played by the Robert De Niero looking,looking as if he's DiNero's identical twin, actor Elias Koteas. As we and Daniel's soon find out Laddis,whom he's been tracking down for the last two years, is in fact one of the mental patients at Ashecliffe Hospital!

Get yourself ready for a number big surprises as both Marshall's Daniels & Aule uncover a major psych ops operation going on at Ashecliffe Hospital. It seems that Doctor's Cawley & Neahring, by copying what the North Koreans did to helpless US POWS in the Korean War, are using the patients there in a number of drug induced mind altering experiments by turning them into mindless and murderous zombies for the US Government in future,like political assassinations, clandestine operations! But what turns out to be the true reason for why Daniels and Aule were assigned there is far more shocking that even that!

***SPOILERS*** One of the best psychological thriller in years that ranks right up there with movies like "The Manchurian Candidate" and 1956 Kevin McCarthy thriller "Nightmare" the film "Sutter Island" will keep you as well as Marshall Daniels & Aule guessing until it reveals the truth about what's really happening in it. The ending of the movie is truly shocking even if you saw it coming miles or minutes in advance! It turns everything that you saw up to that point in the film upside down and even more mind boggling shows who the real villain or villains, as well as good guys or heroes, in the movie really are!

title: Genius unfortunately overlooked by Inception
review:
I watched both Shutter Island and Inception well after their initial cinema releases and chose Inception first, but despite the hype of the film I was very disappointed considering I'd set my hopes high. However with Shutter Island it was less anticipated and a huge surprise as it quickly became one of my favourite films. Originally I was expecting a horror film as the both the trailers and the narrative had not struck me that this was going to be a thriller. As always in a Scorsese film the atmosphere is established from the first shot with what appears to be the main character and his 'detective partner' on a ferry heading to the island in which the film is set.

The film wastes no time in getting straight into the plot and exploring the characters and it is through the interactions between these characters that suspicions arise. The plot is quite complex and requires attention from the viewer, but the experience is far more enjoyable if you can stay connected to the unpredictability of the story. The enigmatic lead role 'teddy' played by Di Caprio is of huge importance as the psychological side of the character is the centre of the plot and delivers the twists throughout the film.

Possibly the best part of this film is its ending which has been built up by all other events of the film and gradually unearthed the truth about 'teddy'. However the interpretation of the end of the film can be different as the view that I have is not the same as what others have said. Overall Shutter Island is a must watch, it delivers an intelligent narrative with elements taken from other Scorsese films, a powerful acting performance and is a film which doesn't have the sole purpose just to make money unlike Inception.

title: For once, the people are right
review:
I don't think this fill garnered much critical praise, but going by the voting on IMDb and the estimated gross earnings of this film, it certainly seems to have been a popular success.

How surprising this is, considering it is such a dark film with a modernist approach to cinema.

Normally, I am with the critics. Most blockbusters (fair enough, this is hardly a blockbuster, but you get my drift) are just dreadful films, but they pull in the punters. And why not, as the Man says. Everyone has to make a living, and turning celluloid into profit is what Hollywood has been doing best for almost a century. Well done Hollywood, I say.

To those who knock the studios all I have to say is: most of the time when you sit down to watch a film, you have some idea of what to expect and if if you don't like blockbusters DON'T GO AND SEE THEM!

But I digress; Shutter Island is hardly a blockbuster. But it was and is popular. It has a strong following but few (if any) of the reviews I have read of the film were impressed.

Well, in this case, the critics are just wrong. This is one of Scorcese's best films. Yep, I mean that. For the maker of Taxi Driver and Goodfellas, I would rate Shutter Island as among his best.

Let's make a prediction - long after Scorcese has gone and the film historians of the future are considering his work, they will regard Shutter Island as his most profound. I know, you scoff. I am and idiot. Yeah, yeah, maybe so. But look, watch the film and let me know, eh?

title: A prodigious expansion to Scorsese's movie cannon!
review:
A surprising mindbending mystery from Scorsese. A classic film noir and one of the most wonderfully crafted psychological thrillers! I've always been impressed by Dennis Lehane's story plots. This is one of the movies which would be better in second time viewing. All the pieces of puzzles you couldn't comprehend the first time, you will in the second time!

Great writer, great actor and one of the greatest directors combine for a prodigious experience. They make an excellent team. A film that will leave you with plenty of thoughts and searching for answers. Another solid film in Scorsese's cannon! Must Watch. Longlive Scorsese!

title: A unique Hitchcock style film at last from the USA
review:
Having worked as a male nurse in an Institution similar to this, I found this film mesmerizing and well crafted. I am a fan of Leonardo and the supporting cast were ace.

It kept me gripped and although my partner found it very frightening I loved it in a clinical way.

A cool sense of fifties style a fab acted film and a gripping plot, well worth buying on DVD.

Cant wait to see Leonardo in the Great Gatsby as he is a fab actor and pleasant on the eye !!

The island setting was just right to build up the atmosphere of the institution, and when they were disarmed at the entrance, I said to myself oh oh, keep track of your pistols guys !

It was pleasant to see a director treating the audience in a mature way for a change rather than gratuitous violent scenes and gore, which bores me, I was ready for this to happen, but was pleasantly surprised.

I haven't read the book but will do as it was engrossing not only as entertainment but as a clinician.

title: Twisting Story Line
review:
The movie Shutter Island is about Teddy Daniels, played by Leonardo DiCaprio, an investigator who is put on an mission to find a patient who has disappeared from the island. Teddy had volunteered to take this mission because he was determined to find and expose his theory that Ashecliffe had been using these patients as lab rats to learn how to control them with drugs and surgery. Teddy begins to have hallucinations of his wife Dolores, played by Michelle Williams, who had been killed in a apartment fire by Andrew Laeddis who was also supposed to be on the island at the hospital as well. When a storm came and shut down all the power on the island the jail cells were all opened and Teddy and his partner Chuck, played by Mark Ruffalo, went into Ward C which is were he thought Laeddis was at. While in there he met George in there which is someone who he had known that originally told him about the secret things going on in that hospital. George told him that Chuck was not really his partner and that all of the doctors were playing a game with him; then went on to tell him that in order to see where they perform the surgeries that he had to go to the lighthouse. Teddy eventually does get to the lighthouse only to find Dr. Cawley, played by Ben Kingsley, who then went on to tell Teddy that he had been at the hospital for two years and that his real name was Andrew Laeddis. He then explained to Teddy that Chuck was not his partner, he was his doctor as well, he just stated with Teddy to make sure that he was safe; and that they allowed him to play the role of an investigator hoping that it would help him to come to the realization that he had actually killed his own wife for killing their children.

Although the movie was not scary in any way to gave off a look as if it were, the lighting was very dark in a lot of shots and with some of the camera angles there it looked as if something was about to happen. All of the characters did a great job with the acting, there was a good twist at the end of the movie that would definitely leave you confused. You may even have to watch it more than once to get a full understanding of what was actually going on in the movie from beginning to end.

title: astonishing...........worth a watch
review: the film is a mind boggling thriller.................. an excellent film from the actors .........you need to keep pace with the film........... over all a great film...........i just have 1 complain.............in my view the film had an abrupt and sudden ending...........the climax could have been different......... except that an excellent film..........1 thing you need to keep in mind is that you need to remember each and every detail of the film ...............otherwise you may not get the story....................the dark settings give you the thrilling mood......ben kingsley was awesome in the negative role.....lastly i recommend to watch the film to blow off your mind...........do not miss it

title: Hauntingly powerful performance by Dicaprio!
review:
"Shutter Island" stands out from the usual batch of generic, rehashed, remakes or just plain stupid, movies they are cranking out as fast as they can these days.

US Marshal Teddy Daniels is investigating a case of missing patient in an institute for dangerous mentally insane people. Along his investigation, he discovers that he is in a midst of a deep conspiracy. I won't go too much into the plot but I'll say this: The execution is nearly perfect. Shocking moments are delivered suddenly and swiftly. The twists and turns will keep anyone guessing throughout the movie. Intense, thrilling scenes which will keep a viewer's heart thumping are scattered throughout the film. Even after the final twist is revealed, the viewer can't help but suspect it due to the many deceptions before.

My only complaints would be the use of really loud music and pointless nudity which could've been easily avoided. If you're looking for a good thriller look no further. It's not 100% original but it will keep you intrigued and entertained, which is more than I can say for 99% of the movies Hollywood is blowing out of it's butt currently.

title: Dicaprio is good!
review: All the actors in the movie are in top-form. Once again, you can't go wrong with a Leonardo DiCaprio/Martin Scorsese collaboration. As the protagonist, we the audience are thrust into his shoes and we are about as confused and scared as his character is, we feel what he feels. It becomes a psychological trip that poses many, many questions about oneself, that to discuss them here would spoil the entire movie. There are some flashbacks in the movie, but all of them are important clues to DiCaprio's character. DiCaprio gives a stunning performance, once again tempting the Academy to give him another Best Actor nomination. DiCaprio gives a vivid portrayal of a vulnerable, haunted and ultimately terrified man. Apart from DiCaprio there's really not much I can say about the supporting cast, because they are all also terrific. Ben Kingsley; Mark Ruffalo; Michelle Williams; Max Von Sydow; Jackie Earle Haley; Emily Mortimer; Patricia Clarkson; Ted Levine; Elias Koteas; John Carroll Lynch. All of them.

title: Odd little Cast Away-Invasion of the Body Snatchers mash up which works a lot better than it has any right to.
review:
Is Martin Scorsese's Shutter Island a police procedural thriller? A horror movie? Is it a film about someone offered the chance to this time uncover (and thus save) those being held against their will by an exterior force seemingly ungoverned by the rest of a broader representation of a community? Well, yes and no and then yes again and then no and then........well, to go on would be to reveal too much. Rest assured, the film is deceptively simplistic but at the same time non-cryptically complicated – or should that be deceptively complicated and non-cryptically simplistic? It is a film about a lead plunged into a situation that sees him with the capability to help a batch of helpless people trapped on the titular Shutter Island who're falling victim to all manner of sordidness, this at a time when recent demons of having stumbled across a Nazi concentration camp long after it was too late to do anything still resonate. At least, for the most part it is a film about this – irregardless of the bumpy, rickety road full of holes and lumps Scorsese takes us down, Shutter Island suffices as a piece of drama you're be hard pressed not to recommend.

The film follows a Bostonian man named Teddy Daniels, played with an impeccably balanced amount of remorse; fear and anger throughout by that of Leonardo Di Caprio. Daniels is a U.S. Marshall, and is assigned to the titular Shutter Island located off the coast of off Boston Harbor. The island is a place not unfamiliar to grey weather and storms, although rather more so to people stepping off its lone mode of transportation both to and from it in the form of ferry and onto its ground by those who think they can come along and boss about the individuals running it. Daniels is one of these people; a man there to look for someone based on the island who rather recently simply disappeared overnight, but not there to take orders from Ben Kingsley's chief doctor in residence, John Cawley. The two men and their antagonism is apparent from the beginning: where Cawley gives a brief outline of the sorts of people he has on this island of containment and rehabilitation, he is quick to label them "patients" present to be cured, with Daniels equally quick to counteract with his view that they are "prisoners" omnipresent so as to be punished for crimes.

Daniels nurses some painful events from his past, namely that of that aforementioned wartime discovery of a German concentration camp and the fact that he recently lost his wife. Daniels is there with a fresh face in U.S. Marshalling: that of Mark Ruffalo's Chuck Aule; a guy who verbally establishes Daniels' reputation as a guy to be reckoned with in this career field as they chug on over through the mist and mire to the island. Initial clashings between the somewhat gruff and more carefree investigative duo of Aule and Daniels and that of Cawley and his German psychiatrist Jeremiah Naehring (von Sydow) escalate beyond mere face value; appearance and the nature of how it is they carry out their investigative work: getting out and about searching for clues consequently lined up alongside that of using studies in psychology to uncover truths about people and past situations "prisoners" or "patients" were dramatically involved in.

Daniels begins to suspect the powers that be on the island are holding back on information, and he launches a crusade going against all the location's rules to try and figure out a bigger picture he believes is at foot – something which intensifies when the person shows up anyway and the film tries to tap into the paranoia and fear rife throughout the respective era in America born out of U.F.O. cover-up conspiracies and Communism infiltration fears. Like his 1976 film Taxi Driver, Scorsese is more than apt at distilling the reality of a lead's world through his own broken subconscious; that is to say, constructing a view of a place (or person, as was evident in The King of Comedy) so intensified that we are propelled into seeing the same object in the same fashion as we're launched into this lead's life and mind. There is about enough substance to keep this 2010 effort grounded throughout, the deft touches implemented during the course of the film allowing a continuous flow of cause, effect and reveal which adds to a burning sense of horror and things seemingly become clearer.

Without Scorsese's deft hand, the film may very well have broken down into farce long before the end credits and one fantastic example of his ability to just move and weave things along is evident when one of the island's chief wardens picks the lead up whilst he was out and about by himself in the forests of the locale following a string of 'reveals' which apparently tell of a greater, darker secret the place holds. Upon picking him up, we are suddenly aware of just how akin to a Nazi Gestapo uniform this warden's clothing actually looks and we think back to if it had always looked like that or whether the film is just toying with us in the immediate present. The film is not the great character study, nor extended piece of narrative film-making, that pieces like 1995's Casino or 1980's Raging Bull were; films playing out across this exasperated amount of time as tensions and distrust boil over between people we never particularly liked. Moreover, it is a genre piece feeding off twists and turns which we accept in a film made by someone we do not feel uneasy in the hand of – the likes of which need not be avoided.

title: No Tropical Paradise!
review:
Leonardo Di Caprio is one of my favourite actors. His performances are flawless and enthralling. I know I'm going to see something special when I watch him perform. He is a fearless actor who makes a difficult craft look simple. He has heart and soul. He's the real deal as far as I'm concerned. Shutter Island is a psychological thriller that keeps you guessing right to the end. It's cleverly directed by Martin Scorsese. The script adapted by Laeta Kalogridis is from Dennis Lehane's novel. The story is set in 1954 on a remote, harsh island. There's nothing tropical and relaxing about this island. It is surrounded by craggy rocks, far from the mainland. The only way onto the island is by ferry. Those who are sent to the island never leave. They are the criminally insane. The most violent, and twisted men and women who are locked up, chained, drugged and experimented on.

US Marshall Teddy Daniels and his partner Chuck are sent to the island to investigate the disappearance of one of the patients who escaped and is believed to be hiding somewhere on the island. Her disappearance is a mystery and a search begins that reveals some shocking truths of what is really happening on this unforgiving, dangerous island where no one can be trusted.

I can highly recommend it as a very well written and directed film with excellent acting performances all round. Ben Kingsley plays psychologist, Dr. Cawley, Mark Ruffalo plays Chuck and Michelle Williams plays Dolores.

title: Shutter Island (2010)
review: A film with all the right talent. Based on a novel by Lehane, Directed by Scorsese and starring DiCaprio, everyone does a fine job, but play it far too safe. The film is just painfully obvious, but luckily in an enjoyable B-Movie kind of way. It's an island with no escape and the authorities seem as mad as those they are in charge of. If you write down 5 guesses as to what the twist is, chances are you'll get it right. It looks good, and Scorsese's talent does allow for some more memorable artistic moments, such as the dream sequences, but this could have been made for television. Some blink and you'll miss them supporting roles from Koteas and Haley are very welcome. It's DiCaprio and Scorsese having a lot of fun, but the biggest twist would have been having no twist at all.

title: The Ultimate Movie Review! - http://tss5078.blogspot.com
review: "Is it better to live as a monster or to die as a good man?" That is the last line in this mind bending thriller from Martin Scorsese. It perfectly describes this film, which I can honestly say is one of the smartest and most savvy films I have ever seen. Leonardo DiCaprio gives his best performance to date. I've seen a lot of DiCaprio, since Titanic, we all have, and this is by far the best he's ever been. How he didn't win an Academy Award for this role is beyond me! The story is very strong and very smart. It's evident that they took their time with this one, in order to get every detail right. The ending is of course the best part. It leaves you scratching your head, going over everything you've just seen and keeps you thinking for hours. No matter how many times you see this movie, you'll always pick up on something new, each and every time. It was an amazing movie and I can't recommend it enough!

title: Magnificent movies like Shutter Island must be seen and felt
review: I admit I haven't seen a much better mystery plot like the one on the Scorsese's movie Shutter Island. This mystery,intrigue and curiosity of what's going to happen next fills us since at the very beginning fog scene. But the movie itself wouldn't be so great without its music, Mahler's quartet for piano and strings in a minor at Dr.Naehring introduction in the movie causing the main character Teddy's(starring Di Caprio) flashback about years ago when he liberated the Dachau Konzentrationslager from Nazis and executed them all. The music is important because it touches our heart's wires more then the visual part,as in the dream and nightmare sequences of Teddy. The music throughout the movie mostly expresses pain( Teddy's memories), suspanse and scare(first nightmare scene at Dachau), but Mahler's strings in a minor at a particular part became very ironic and sarcastic showing that this movie has all the colors of the rainbow. Good job !

title: Scorsese's Back On His A Game
review:
After Casino (back in 95) Marty Scorsese was directing fantastic movies and after a couple drops, following the utterly horrible 'Gangs Of New York' he redeemed himself with "The Departed" and this movie. It follows the story of ex-soldier sent to mental hospital to find a missing patient.

The Movie starts out like a typical noir mystery flick and about an hour into it.. it instantly becomes more psychological when we learn more about the characters background, with a couple mind boggling twists that'll keep you confused for quite a while (you'll have to watch it again) it's definitely worth checking and worthy of your DVD/Blu-Ray Collection.

Check This Flick Out!

title: A movie worth artistic acclaim, but not entertainment applause
review:
The movie issued earlier than Inception, why do I compare than together is the scheme they were trying to make to engage the topic of reality and dreams. (The following comments include some spoils in the movie)

Inception is conscious traveling between dreams, this one is the opposite. The difficulty of the topic is how to make people feel suspense in the movie, in this part, I can only say they failed. I can tell what would happen in the end, obviously many people does, because the theme here is being done too many times. Modern people who love thriller or mystic movies would find out disappoint because the movie would not satisfy them.

However, it would not decline the joy of watching the movie to me. The atmosphere is tense, everyone showed great acting skill in the movie, moreover, the scene created with very artistic visual impact, it did good jobs on many aspect of a good movie. Not being critical, it's a very enjoyable movie to me, just people who likes more complicated thrill movie would not satisfy.

title: "One of Scorsese' best!"
review:
Without doubt this is one of my favourite films of last year, so here is my review, enjoy!

Plot Summary Shutter Island, adapted for the big screen from the book by Denis Lehane, is the story of U.S Marshall Teddy Daniels (DiCaprio) who is sent to Shutter Island, a spooky looking, fog covered island home to a mental institute for the criminally insane. He is too investigate the escape and disappearance of an inmate at the institute along with the help of his partner Chuck (Rufallo).

What I thought of it I must admit, I'm quite the fan of Leonardo DiCaprio, a lot of my favourite films have him in ('Departed', 'Inception', 'Catch Me If You Can' etc) so I was quietly confident that this was going to be another great of his especially as, like 'departed', it was directed by Martin Scorsese.

All of my pre-conceptions were true when watching this, both DiCaprio and Ruffalo give great memorable performances. DiCaprio's role turns out to be a very dark role, in which his character is struggling mentally with so much, not just with the job at hand but also the loss of his wife in an apartment fire. Throughout the film these thoughts going through his head get harder to ignore and completely change the character, which DiCaprio portrays exceedingly well.

Both actor and director do a fantastic job of messing with our emotions and feelings in this film, really making us draw strong opinions of certain characters, of which often change throughout the course of the film.

Summary Many people have criticised and labelled this film as being a typical DiCaprio film with a predictable and obvious ending, I must disagree! This film has some great twists and turns of which I expected none, and the performances given by all of the actors involved are some of there personal bests.

I would definitely give this film a watch whether your a fan of DiCaprio or not, this may change your opinion.... 8/10 Stars

title: Yet Another Amazing Film by Martin Scorsese
review:
Once again, Martin Scorsese has made an absolutely amazing movie and has moved up even farther, if possible, on my "all time favorite directors" list. And of course you can not forget Leonardo DiCaprio, someone who is quickly becoming one of my favorite actors, and Mark Ruffalo, someone who I had gained a lot of respect for after seeing Zodiac.

Aside from the amazing cast, the story was great and kept me glued to my seat until the very end. This is the type of film that took me about two watches to catch all of it's hidden messages and the ending was one that kept me thinking about it for along time after viewing it.

As for the length, it is longer than most but people, like some of my friends, who get bored with long movies do not need to worry as there was never a boring second in this entire movie.

All around, it was a great movie that has become one of my favorites and will be hard to beat, but I would not put it past Scorsese to try.

title: The last line of the movie is the movie
review: I just want to give a heads up to viewers that if you miss the last line of the movie, your missing the whole movie. The few people who don't like the movie, are disappointed by the ending, i think they mist that last line which makes the movie. Even if you (like me) think you get the plot of the movie halfway, you will get the real feeling and understanding of the movie when Leonardo says his last line. The whole movie (if you get it) will screw with you're head and may even change the whole view you have on mental illness. There is this accepted view that mental illness is a disease which they can do nothing about. You want to help those people get better. But this movie explains that the reality can be much different from this accepted view. The last line of the movie explains this. Thats a reason why you cant miss it, to get this movie.

title: incredible
review: Let's face it , this production is the best psychological movie ever made ! The facts , the place where the action is taking part , everything is perfect chosen by the director Martin Scorsese , who became very appreciated by my eyes after this movie . And the cast is extraordinary chosen , the main characters being played by Leonardo DiCaprio , Mark Ruffalo and Ben Kingsley , actors with a large experience in this domain . Is hard to create and direct such facts , such events and such a movie , and especially for this reason this peace of art is so appreciated , particularly for it's originality ! For me , was a huge surprise to see it and completely satisfied at the end of it ... and still i'm wondering : is really Teddy Daniels a psychopath ?

title: A disappointment
review:
After all these years, Scorsese is yet to have made a bad movie; while contemporaries Spielberg and Coppola sunk to mediocrity long ago, Scorsese is still one of the most versatile and skilled directors in the world. Shutter Island is no exception; it's not a bad movie. But it's not a great movie either.

Funnily enough, Scorsese, who used to stand at the forefront of avant-garde and artistic cinema in Hollywood, serves in the new millennium as the voice of classic, old-school cinema, often verging on nostalgia. That works perfectly in the often bashed The Departed, which was unpretending piece of straight entertainment. The problem with Shutter Island - an obvious call back to thrillers of the 40's and 50's, to Carol Reed, Hitchcock and Wilder - is that it tries to be more, and as a psychological film of substance and depth it barely succeeds.

It's a terrific success as an entertaining, gripping thriller though - that is, as long as you repress the urge we have as modern viewers to take the twist ending as the most important element in the film; because the twist ending is quite predictable and almost anti-climatic, it can easily disappoint if you put too much emphasis on it, and it's easy to miss the fact that the moment of reveal wasn't meant to be the film's climax. Shutter Island makes no new discoveries - there's no real insight and there's no real mystery. There's lots of atmosphere, solid acting, fantastic music, editing and cinematography, and above all - entertainment. Taken like that at face value, it's quite enjoyable, but don't expect a revelation.

title: Shutter Island
review:
In "Shutter Island," director Martin Scorsese presents a dark and twisted mystery, chockfull of heroes and villains. What makes the film exceptionally intriguing is the way the line between reality and fantasy is blurred.

The film is based on Dennis Lehane's novel and stars award winning actors and nominees Leonardo DiCaprio and Mark Ruffalo. It was screened at my local movie theater, a dilapidated building one step behind the time. You get what you pay for, which can be a good or bad thing. But the cheap ticket and food price and short lines add to the experience, and, ironically tied into the obscure film. "Shutter Island" takes place during the Cold War, a turbulent time enriched with conspiracy. U.S. Marshal Teddy Daniels (DiCaprio), and his partner Chuck (Ruffalo) team up on an investigation to Shutter Island, to investigate a missing person, Rachel Solando (Emily Mortimer), who mysteriously disappeared. The Island is home to a mental hospital that cures the criminally insane. It's located off the coast of Boston, but seems miles away from civilization and sanity. Once the investigation is underway, Daniels becomes suspicious. He thinks the institution is keeping secrets and spinning a web of corruption. And then out of nowhere, Solando is found. This detail begins the series of confusing mind games during the film. You begin to realize something strange is occurring, but you're left confused, musing over the possibilities. Daniels' investigation transforms into a relentless investigation of his own personal demons. He's forced to confront his past, hallucinations of his dead wife that become frequent as he loses grasp on reality. At this point in the movie, things become thrilling. The only way to get off the island is by ferry, which the authorities control. Daniels becomes trapped, physically and mentally. Suspense heightens as he desperately tries to distinguish truths from lies, unravel the hidden secrets embedded in the island, before he turns mad. Between the investigation, Daniels' hallucination, and the mysterious behavior of the hospital staff, "Shutter Island's" plot becomes a dramatic blur. The audience spends the entire film trying to understand what's happening, paralleling with Daniels experience of grasping reality. Warning: if you don't like puzzles or brainteasers avoid this film at all costs, because you are essentially paying for a mind game. The end of the movie is flipped. Daniels is cast as insane and the institution's presented in a new light. With all the chatter of frustration filling the theater, it sounded as if the audience was sent on a whirlwind.

A simple "Google" search for possible endings points into a direction of various theories. But, maybe the whole point of the movie is not to determine what exactly happened, but to get you to think in the first place. The beauty of this is, the story can unfold both ways. Each hypothesis can be supported with different evidence. This hazy line between the reality and fantasy is what makes "Shutter Island" a cinematic enigma. You're in for a dark surprise.

title: One word: Amazing
review:
Not only does the movie have you guessing and figuring things out then entire time but its got action, suspense and at some points it'll make you jump.

The actors did an amazing job playing their roles and the film was pieced together perfectly. A very satisfying mystery movie FINALLY! I've seen the movie about 5 times and i still love watching it, takes alittle while to figure it all out. I would happily recommend this movie to anyone (maybe not children there are swears) and tell you to buckle down and get ready to think because you'll be confused the entire time.

title: A very well crafted thriller
review:
Of all the Scorcese movies ever made, surprisingly, this would have to be one of the best. It follows Teddy Daniels, a Boston based US Marshal in 1954, who is sent to Shutter Island, an island off the coast of Massachusetts, to find a missing patient who has escaped from a mental hospital.

What makes Shutter Island such a good film is the way in which it never fails to keep the audience entertained and interested in what is going to happen next. It uses sophisticated dialouge which is timed, crafted and acted perfectly.

The acting from Leonardo Di Caprio as Marshal Teddy Daniels and Ben Kingsley as the founder of the mental hospital which is known as Ashecliffe mental hospital for the criminally insane, is probably the best acting in the movie, and what also makes this fantastic movie so great is the way that it manages to make its horror and thrills so stylish.

One of the best movies of 2010, definitely well worth the watch.

title: I am pretty sure if you don't like it.. you don't get it.
review:
I will try to avoid spoilers if I can. But better to be on the safe side. I am not some film buff or student who is in love with his thesaurus. But i really think if you hate this film for what ever reasons you are missing the point. No its not scary.. but yes its a fantastically well written film. When he finally remembers the moment with his wife and kids its one of the most moving scenes in modern cinema.

There is a constant stream of absolutely banal films pouring out at us and this is one film that made me think, and moved me to tears at one point .I also completely missed the twist until it was explained which made the second watch brilliant. If you found it boring or tedious or obvious.. ( probably is obvious if somebody tells you the twist before you watch it.. ) well then thats your loss as its one of the best films made in the last 10 years.

title: Go With The Flow........
review:
In today's world, we humans rarely, if ever, compliment someone for doing a job well done. We are quick to criticize, but slow to congratulate good work. Perhaps because we see more bad than good. The movie Shutter Island, however, is an example of good (perhaps great) work and why I am taking the time to publicly say so.

For me, most of the movies made today stink. This is because the story-lines/scripts are usually moronic, full of logic holes and silliness. This movie is different in that the overall story makes sense and -at the end- left me with a complete feeling of satisfaction. It is a movie that requires patience. I found the first 1 hr and 45 minutes required me to watch and listen, but not think. To basically, "GO WITH THE FLOW". To try to guess the ending or anticipate what would come next was, for me, a waste of time and would ultimately only ruin this movie.

In my opinion, this movie has three things in its favor. A great script, strong acting and excellent directing. The first part of this movie sets the stage while the last 30 minutes provide the climax and tie all that has gone before together, which is why it pays to watch and listen.

Shutter Island is an excellent (horror, thriller, mind games, you decide) film. As an earlier reviewer said and I quote: "There is one line of dialogue, right at the end of Shutter Island before the credits roll, that elevates the emotion of the film and makes it much more powerful.". I gave this movie 9 out of 10 stars not because it does not deserve 10, but because as I said before I spent the early part of the movie more as an observer than as a participant. It was not until near the end of the movie that I felt emotionally connected. This is an excellent movie and something VERY rare in today's world A movie worthy of public compliment.

title: Scorsese not your best.
review:
I love Martin Scorsese and I love Leo but I have to tell you I did not love this. Don't get me wrong the acting and direction was amazing. You cant expect anything less from this team of cinema masters. Though I though the story line fell a little short.

This movie is about a detective who goes to an insane asylum to investigate a missing person. When he gets there he soon starts to discover weird things going on and even weirder leads leading him to the missing person.

I thought this movie was alright. Let me tell you first that if it ended 20 minutes sooner I would have given it a lot higher of a rating. It is just not like Scorsese to make a movie like this and for that i was highly disappointed. Overall though if you have an open mind and don't know much about Scorsese then this one is probably fine for you. If you love classic Scorsese Im not sure this one will do it for you.

title: Just dropped in - to see what condition my condition was in...
review:
"The mind is its own place, and in itself can make a heaven of hell, a hell of heaven." --John Milton, Paradise Lost.

What a beautiful, sophisticated, mind-leveling thriller! SHUTTER ISLAND is not "scary," but creepy, disturbing and filled with enough tension and intrigue to drown a plush toy.

1954: Detective Teddy Daniels (Leo DiCaprio) and his partner Chuck (Mark Ruffalo) on a mission to Shutter Island, an institution for the criminally insane, to investigate the disappearance of a female murderer. The head warden Dr. Cawley (Ben Kingsley) outlines the mystery "as if she evaporated through the walls."

As Teddy carries out his investigation, things start to fall out of place more readily than they fall into it, and events start to lead Teddy to the conclusion that everyone is conspiring to let this dangerous criminal disappear without helping him locate her. Why then, was he brought here? And why can't he leave? At first, it's because a raging storm cuts off the ferry service. And then...well...

SHUTTER ISLAND conjures those fears of walking into a psyche ward and not being able to walk out again, because people start treating YOU as insane. Didn't we learn anything from ONE FLEW OVER THE CUCKOO'S NEST? Teddy arrived with his partner Chuck; halfway through his stay, Dr. Cawley begins asking him, "What partner? You came here alone."

One of the characters nails the paradox: "People tell the world you're crazy, and all your protests to the contrary just confirm what they're saying. Once you're declared insane, then anything you do is called part of that insanity; any reasonable protests are denial, any valid fears are paranoia..."

Ruffalo is enjoyable as always, bringing a breezy humor to what could have turned into a darker role; Max von Sydow brings enough dark for everyone as a foreboding old doctor; even Elias Koteas, a prisoner whose face looks like it was put together by Victor Frankenstein, isn't as scary as von Sydow; Patricia Clarkson makes an intriguing appearance as a woman hiding out in a cave, who may just be who Teddy is looking for. Or she may just be a figment of his imagination. Or our imagination. Or maybe we're just watching INCEPTION and need to stop kidding ourselves that they'll let us out of here alive...

From a novel by Dennis Lehane, Martin Scorcese directs - or should that be "misdirects"? - brilliantly, never revealing enough information to give away the game, yet egging us on with just enough to tie us into a straightjacket. SHUTTER ISLAND is a Hitchcockian mind-bender that springs such a head trip in its last few minutes that you will watch it again immediately with completely new eyes. And you will see every clue hidden subtly in plain sight.

Further, deponent sayeth not.

title: Amazing.
